Comments_List: learned about planning and zoning
Practices of urban planning
An understanding of what an urban planner is thinking about when making design decisions.

This class was an excellent survey course about evolution of planning practice with ample case studies in Northeast U.S. region (CT/NY/NJ). Professor Kooris and the readings he selects impart to students a comprehensive understanding of major key terms in the planning space - and the course is designed to help students begin to make complex connections among weekly topics, from zoning code and urban deign guidelines to transit-oriented development planning (effectively, like a planner would - wedding a variety of different considerations/interests).
I gained exposure and knowledge into a wide range of urban planning topics and challenges, and I was able to read and think about these topics within the context of a particular city of choice.

Upon taking this course, I now have a much better understanding of urban, suburban, and regional planning. Prior, I did not have a good grasp on local/city zoning, street development, and transit oriented development, but after taking Prof. Kooris's class and learning from his unique insights I have a much better understanding of the topics as well as the resources applicable to these areas.

This is a great introductory course into the field of planning. It provides a good combination of lectures, readings, group work and independent research. The group work was beneficial in allowing students to apply the ideas they are learning about to real cities and think about how the different pieces fit together for a real community. It also allows students to be creative and develop solutions to community specific challenges. The paper allowed for a deeper dive into a subject area of the student's choice. Overall, this class helped me have a better understanding of the history of planning, different strategies planners have had throughout the last two centuries, the different elements of a comprehensive plan, and more recent focus on resilience and climate change from the planning perspective.
Broad understanding of planning concepts and history. Why does our built environment look and work the way it does....
I gained a fuller understanding of the extensive field of planning. I found it very relevant to have conversations about contemporary events.
intro to the aspects of city planning.
Learned how urban planning works, who is involved, and what is involved.

-Great to do some individual research on the term paper and also really enjoyed doing the group work to get some insight in how people with very different work flows and prior experiences approach problems and think about the same issue very differently. 
-The field trip to the planning commission was really insightful and engaging. Clarified a lot of stuff we talked about in class.
Intro and topic specific into sustainability urban planning

Much of this course is based around David's professional experiences. Hearing about his work provides real insights into the challenges and barriers that professionals experience, especially working for government. I appreciated this perspective, although he sometimes went on big tangents.
Urban planning concepts ranging from regional planning to resilience

I learned a great deal about the history and evolution of urban planning throughout the 20th and 21st centuries. I am focusing on land conservation at FES, and I took this course to complement some of my studies in that field because I think that it's important for conservationists to have a grasp of the other side of the coin, development.

David was great in setting up each class under a particular theme, whether it was a history lesson or a particular aspect of planning (zoning, transit-oriented development, etc.) Each week's lecture had a lot of information in that particular area, but the course itself built on each week's knowledge. 

We talked not only about cities but about suburbs and regions, and how development in those areas has been impactful as well.

The group project also allowed us practice diagnosing urban planning problems in a particular city, which was a neat exercise designed to get us thinking about how we would work if we were planners. 

I also particularly enjoyed the final research paper because I was able to really dive into a topic of particular interest to me.

As a result of this course, I am more thoughtful when I go out into urban environments. I'm able to get a better sense of development patterns - what that place did right and what could have been done better. It also has given me perspective as I think about my future career - I don't necessarily want to be a planner but I think an understanding of the concepts will be critical to my conservation work and understanding of how problems arise in urban and suburban environments.
it was good
Urban planning in action
Well.

I went into the course hoping to clarify my understanding of the urban planning space, what the profession entails, and how the profession has (in different ways) shaped the cities/suburban areas we inhabit.In particular, the weekly group assignments that asked us to apply each week's lecture and reading material to analyze a city of our choice helped to solidify concepts learned in class - and move beyond abstract urban theory.

The level of engagement and depth in this class surpassed my expectations. The course enabled students to bring in and discuss their own insights and interests, and Professor Kooris went into a lot of depth about how idealistic urban planning topics are handled and managed in practice.

Prior to enrolling in this class I heard nothing but praise for Prof. Kooris and my class expectations were exceeded. I really developed an appreciation for Prof. Kooris's passion and practical knowledge on the subject matter, which made the class very beneficial for me.
It met my expectations.
It aligned perfectly with my expectations.

Very much so. I expected a class steeped in the practical matters of planning and that is exactly what it was. As an architecture student, I found it very refreshing to take a class that was so in tune with the world outside of school.

We covered the concepts I expected to cover. I would have liked the assignments to be a little more skills-based. I also think the final paper could have been better if it were more of a consulting project.
Very good and interesting!
Pretty well. I thought the classes with slideshows were much more effective than the others that were, even though there were no visuals, very well presented.
Yes, great class

I got what I expected out of this class - I had heard it was a great course and it was. I learned a lot, from David's lectures and his personal anecdotes about being an important person in planning in Connecticut, as well as the assignments and field trips.

strength: it was good to be able to talk to someone outside of academia
weakness: no access to the class slides

This lectures are very good. David provides numerous anecdotes from his work. I did not learn much from the group assignments though. For some reasons, we have stopped discussing the readings after several lectures.
Great lecturer.  Field trips were fun too.  Break in the middle of class helped.
I wish we had more feedback throughout the course on our group assignments so we could continue to improve them week-to-week.

This course is very much an overview, but would be a good introductory class for further engagement in urban and land use classes. Sometimes I felt that the news/current events portion of the class was too long and took away from the core of the lectures, so I would limit the amount of time that can take up. Finally, I thought that the lectures with powerpoint slides were more effective at conveying the overarching concepts and information in the lecture than those without powerpoint slides.

The strengths of the course are Prof. Kooris's experience and practice in planning and course content, the field trips and access to local/ real-world planning activities, creative and flexible group research projects, and the open-ended nature of the course that allowed student interests and current events to guide discussion. There were no true weaknesses to the course, however, I would have liked for movement through some discussion topics to proceed at a slower pace.

David is a great asset to the FES community. It feels like he knows everyone in the planning world and has been an integral part of Connecticut planning over the last decade. He has so much experience to share with the class that is really valuable. The readings were also really great and the group projects were fun and interesting. 

The one weakness of this course was that it sometimes felt a little disorganized, and some of his final lectures felt less structured than the initial ones. I think organization and structure are really important for a 3 hour class, especially an evening one when everyone is tired anyway. It also would have been nice to get our grades back on the group projects earlier in the semester, so we could know how we were doing on them before working on more.
Course was at its best when instructor was teaching with visual aides and incorporating examples from is experience.
I would have appreciated more slide presentations for the last lectures.
Maybe take out a couple of the topics to go more in-depth with the others.
Very interesting and knowledgable professor, great speaker.
Professor Kooris has hands on and broad knowledge of politics and economics of urban planning.

Great anecdotes from real professional situations (especially in the tri-state area), and good to learn all the urban planning terminology.

The weakness was that the course felt pretty unstructured at times and some of the lectures were a bit rambling.
Strengths- Instruction, assignment feedback, field visit

Strengths: David is a great teacher: he has so much to say on each topic and is such an expert in his field that it was a lot of fun to be taught by him His anecdotes about his work experiences were funny and informative. He is so clearly passionate about planning, and teachers who are passionate about their subject are the best kind. The field trips were also a lot of fun and highly informative. We did a walking tour of Stanford CT and attended a planning commission meeting in New Haven. Both field trips were great. Also, Katie Murray was a great TA!

Weaknesses: The class time. Not David's fault, and I know he has a day job. But Wednesday night class time was difficult because it was 3 hours and by that point in the evening, I'd been at school since 9am and was just hungry and ready to go home. It's hard to pay attention at that hour no matter how great the class. In addition, there were a couple of lectures that David didn't have powerpoint slides for, and that made it a little difficult to stay engaged.
Good intro to planning and zoning but not in depth
Take it if you already have some theoretical background in urban planning.
The lectures are fascinating.
Absolutely take it if you think you might have an interest in urban planning!
I recommend taking the time to read the course reading materials in order to maximize the knowledge that you get out of the course.

If you are interested in local/state/regional planning and/or climate change adaptation at these levels then this course will be stimulating and beneficial to you. Prof. Kooris has extensive experience working in this field and connects his insights to interesting literature. The workload for the course is very fair and Prof. Kooris is often available before and after class. I would highly recommend this course!

This is a great course if you can be flexible and go with the flow of slightly unstructured lectures. David covers a lot of really important and interesting material throughout the course but sometimes that information is more anecdotal than a normal class. However, it is still really enjoyable for a student interested in planning.
It you are interested in urban planning take this class!
Do the readings! It was easy to ignore those since we didn't really engage with them in class.
Take it!

It's good as a primer, overview of themes of planning. It lacks quite a bit of structure. I'd really like to see what Seto would teach or outliner her course in planning. I think this course could be improved it incorporated a bit more theory/ideas to chew on rather than just very practical and current knowledge.
Strongly recommended
Be ok with the course being somewhat open ended and unstructured, and expect much of the value-ad to be related to David's professional experience.
Recommend pairing with Urban resilience or Land use seminar course

This is a fantastic course! David is a great resource and so knowledgable. The workload is about the same as an average FES class, but it felt very manageable to me given how much work my other classes this semester were. My one regret with this course is actually that my other classes had so much work that I was unable to complete devote myself to the work of this class, and had to do things like skip readings and such. It was a shame, because this was one of my favorite classes I've taken at FES and I wish I could have been able to really put 100% effort into it. That said, I still learned a lot. I'd highly recommend it to folks interested in urban and suburban planning and gaining and understanding of how urban environments inform our understanding of the world.
